How can we help you?

If your child has special educational needs or a disability, you are not alone. We are here to help you get the right support, at every stage.

What is SEND

SEND stands for Special Educational Needs and Disabilities. Your child may have SEND if they need extra help with:

  • learning, reading, writing or maths
  • understanding things or concentrating
  • communicating or making friends
  • their behaviour or emotions
  • a physical disability or health condition that affects their learning

Gloucestershire County Council has a legal duty to identify, assess and support children and young people with SEND from birth to age 25. This support is provided in partnership with schools, health services and social care.

How your child gets support

Support for children with SEND builds up in stages. This is called the graduated approach.

Step 1: Support in school

Every school must try their best to meet your child's needs. This includes good teaching for all pupils and extra help where needed. Your child's teacher and the school's SENDCo (Special Educational Needs Co-ordinator) work together to plan support.

Step 2: Extra targeted support

If your child needs more help, the school puts a SEND Support plan in place. The school uses a cycle of assess, plan, do, review to work out what helps your child learn best. Outside specialists may be brought in to advise.

Step 3: EHC needs assessment

If the support at school is not enough, you or the school can ask the council for an Education, Health and Care (EHC) needs assessment. This is a detailed look at your child's needs. It may lead to an EHC plan, which is a legal document setting out the support your child must receive.

Find out how to request an assessment

Your child's voice matters

The law says that your child's views, wishes and feelings must be listened to throughout the SEND process. This applies at every stage, from school support to EHC assessments and plan reviews.

Young people aged 16 and over have their own legal rights under the Children and Families Act 2014 and can make decisions about their own education and support.

Not sure where to start?

If you are worried about your child's progress or think they might need extra help, here is what to do:

  1. Talk to your child's school — ask to speak with the SENDCo (Special Educational Needs Co-ordinator). Every school must have one.
  2. Contact SENDIASS — they offer free, confidential advice to help you understand your options. Find out more about SENDIASS.
  3. Request an EHC assessment — if your child is not making progress despite school support, you can ask the council for a formal assessment. Find out how.

Need help now?

SENDIASS provides free, impartial advice for families of children and young people with SEND.
